results.title: ‘Legally Blonde’ Oral History: From Raunchy Script to Feminist Classic
results.abstract: Along the way, adult zingers were edited out, Jennifer Coolidge struggled with the “bend and snap” and the ending was changed at least three times.

results.title: Taylour Paige on ‘Zola,’ Grace and Being Kinder to Herself
results.abstract: For the stripper tale, the actress was mindful of the real Zola’s voice: “We’re in service of the bigger truth, the way we as Black women go through the world.”

multimedia.caption: “Zola” is just the latest major film for Taylour Paige in the last year or so. She said, “When I hear ‘breakthrough,’ it is like, ‘OK, but what’s expected of me? What’s expected of Black women?’”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

results.title: Richard Donner, Director of ‘Superman’ and ‘Lethal Weapon’ Films, Dies at 91
results.abstract: The Bronx-born Mr. Donner was in his late 40s when he made his first megahit, about the Man of Steel, but others soon followed, including “The Goonies” and “Scrooged.”

results.title: With ‘Summer of Soul,’ Questlove Wants to Fill a Cultural Void

results.title: Robert Downey Sr., Filmmaker and Provocateur, Is Dead at 85
results.abstract: His movies, most notably “Putney Swope,” didn’t make a lot of money. But they attracted a lot of attention and influenced a lot of younger directors.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Robert Downey Sr. in an undated photo. He once said that the budget for his first film, “Babo 73,” was $3,000.

results.title: Dilip Kumar, Film Star Who Brought Realism to Bollywood, Dies at 98
results.abstract: One of India’s earliest Method actors, he was the last survivor of a triumvirate of actors who ruled Hindi cinema in the 1950s and ’60s.

multimedia.caption: Dilip Kumar, center right, in 2006 with the actor Shah Rukh Khan, center left, in Mumbai. He was one of three Indian movie stars who defined the post-independence Hindi film hero.

results.title: In ‘Monsters at Work,’ the Scary Part Is the New Business Model
results.abstract: Twenty years after Pixar debuted the original “Monsters, Inc.,” Disney+ is bringing a cast of new monsters to the small screen — and putting Mike and Sulley in the managers’ office.

multimedia.caption: “Monsters at Work” picks up where the 2001 Pixar film “Monsters, Inc.” left off, with returning roles for Billy Crystal as Mike (center, with the mop bucket), and John Goodman as Sulley (far right).

results.title: Robert Sacchi, Who Played Bogart Again and Again, Dies at 89
